Dolmenwood/Ability-Scores.title: Ability Scores
Dolmenwood/Ability-Scores.content:
Modifiers
Ability scores add (or subtract) modifiers to damage rolls.
The modifier is calculated (ability score - 10)/2
For ability scores above 12 or above, this will result in a positive modifier. For ability scores 8 or below, this will result in a negative modifier.
Modifiers are rounded to the smallest absolute value, i.e. -1 rounds to 0, +1 rounds to 0. -2 rounds to -1, +2 rounds to +1.
Add the STR modifier to melee damage for slow (d10), and balanced (d8) weapons.
Add the DEX modifier to melee damage for quick (d6) weapons and ranged attacks.
Unarmed and improvised (1d4)  may use either STR or DEX modifiers, but not both.
Add the WIL modifier to the SUM of spell rolls, and rolls to avoid spell miscasts.

Dolmenwood/Character-Creation.title: Character Creation
Dolmenwood/Character-Creation.content:
Roll ability scores
Roll 3d6 three times. Assign each total to one of the ability scores of your choice, STR, DEX and WIl. Enter the numbers in the ‘MAX’ box.
Roll 1d4 and add 10 to get LUCK
Add Modifiers
For each of the three stats, enter the modifier in the MOD column. The modifier is the (stat - 10) /2
For each stat this will give you a modifier between -4 and +4.
Choose a Vocation
Choose one of the Vocations for your character: Cleric, Hunter, Knight, Magician or Thief.
Weapons and Armor
Roll for armor and weapons using the list in your vocation description. Write them in the “On person” section of your character sheet. Most equipment occupies one slot (box) on the character sheet. Some equipment takes more than one slot. Some equipment takes no slots. Anything that takes 0 slots goes in the ‘Skills, Spells, etc.’ section.
Equipment, Skills and Spells
Add the equipment listed in your vocation to either the “on person” section or to your backpack. During combat it takes one action to move an item (or swap two items) from in your backpack to on your person.
Add any class skills or spells
Hit Protection (HP)
Roll the listed die type for your vocation, put it in the MAX Hp box
Motivation
Pick which of these motivations best suits your character:

Helping people
Uncovering mysteries
Seeking treasure

Dolmenwood/Combat.title: Combat
Dolmenwood/Combat.content:
Before damage is rolled, Player Characters under attack have the following options:
Defend
The character tries to defend themselves without taking any particular risks
or trying any moves. This is resolved by simply taking the damage to HP — the default
option.
Fight Back
The defender chooses one attacker and makes an attack, after they’ve
taken the incoming damage. Fighting back incurs 1 Fatigue.
Block
Incoming Fast (d6) or Balanced (d8) attacks become Impaired. To block, the
defender must wield a balanced or slow weapon or a shield. Blocking incurs 1
Fatigue, unless it is performed with a shield or slow weapon while wearing heavy
armor (3 Armor), in which case it incurs no Fatigue.
Dodge
Any incoming Slow (d10) or Balanced (d8) attacks become Impaired. It is not
possible to dodge in heavy armor (3 Armor) or while wielding a slow weapon.
Dodging incurs 1 Fatigue, unless it is performed with a fast weapon (or unarmed)
while wielding light (1 Armor) or no Armor, in which case it incurs no Fatigue.
Parry
The defender chooses one attacking opponent that they are able to attack in
return and make an opposed roll.

If the defender rolls higher than the attacker, the attacker’s dice
roll is invalidated, and the defender deals their damage straight to the attacker’s
STR.
If the attacker rolls higher, the damage is dealt to the defender’s STR instead.
If the two rolls are equal, both weapons bounce off each other. No damage is done to either party.

Each of these options is essentially a reaction — they happen in the split-second in
which a character is attacked. Some enemies might also have access to these abilities
as well. Note that an attacking creature cannot take a reaction; if an orc blademaster
strikes at a PC and the PC fights back, the orc cannot block or take similar reactions, as
that could create an infinite chain of reactions.
Damage
HP represents the character’s ability to avoid harm. While the character is at or above 0 HP, they have not be physically harmed.
Once a character’s HP have been depleted, any additional damage is done to their STR stat. Once the damage

Dolmenwood/Magic.title: Magic
Dolmenwood/Magic.content:
Decide how many dice you are going to use to cast your spell. Some spells may have a minimum number of dice that you must use to successfully cast the spell. The maximum number of dice that a beginning character can use is four. You cannot use more dice than you have empty inventory slots. To use more than four dice the character must get specialized training, or find some other in-game method to increase ability their to use magic.
Spell Descriptions
Some spells have variable effects based on the number and sum of the dice. In the descriptions these will be noted as SUM and DICE.
Rolling the dice
Roll the selected number of magic dice. If any of the dice are repeated (i.e. two 4s, three 2s, two 2s and two sixes), then the spell has become unstable and the caster must roll to control it.
To successfully control the spell: Roll a WIL check against a target of 12 + the number of matching dice.
Example: Zappa is attempting to cast a three die fireball. They roll a 6 and two 1s. Zappa must make a WIL check (WIL + d20) and beat a target number of 14 (12 + 2 for the repeated 1s).
If the check is failed, the player must roll on the magical mishap table.
Magical mishaps do not always result in the failure of the spell.
Fatigue
Whether the spell is successfully cast or not, the character takes one fatigue for each 4,5 or 6 rolled.
Holy magic is incompatible with other types of magic
Any character that has access to holy magic (cleric spells), may not use arcane or other types of magic. If they do, their deity will remove their ability to cast holy spells, or to receive holy blessings
The ability to cast holy magic may be regained by performing a service for the church as penance.
Limited exceptions may be made if the use of arcane magic is of significant benefit to the church.

Dolmenwood/Mechanics.title: Mechanics
Dolmenwood/Mechanics.content:
Checks
Roll 1d20 and add your modifier. The DM will tell you if you succeed or not.
A roll of a natural 20 can indicate a Critical Success (yes, and). A natural one can indicate an exceptional failure (no, and), also called a Fumble.
Modifiers
Ability scores add (or subtract) modifiers to damage rolls.
The modifier is calculated (ability score - 10)/2
For ability scores above 12 or above, this will result in a positive modifier. For ability scores 8 or below, this will result in a negative modifier.
Modifiers are rounded to the smallest absolute value, i.e. -1 rounds to 0, +1 rounds to 0. -2 rounds to -1, +2 rounds to +1.
Add the STR modifier to melee damage for slow (d10), and balanced (d8) weapons.
Add the DEX modifier to melee damage for quick (d6) weapons and ranged attacks.
Unarmed and improvised (1d4)  may use either STR or DEX modifiers, but not both.
Add the WIL modifier to the SUM of spell rolls, and rolls to avoid spell miscasts.
Saves
Make a roll-under save to avoid a bad thing happening. This system is similar to games like Cairn, or 1st and 2nd edition Dungeons and Dragons.
If a character is at risk, the DM will call for a save against the relevant stat. The player rolls 1d20, and is aiming to roll equal or lower than their ability score.

Dolmenwood/Session-0.title: Session 0
Dolmenwood/Session-0.content:
Principles
Living World
Their is no set plot, and the players are free to follow what interests them. All of the factions have their own desires and plans, and will attempt to fulfill them. The players may choose to help or hinder them as they see fit.
Foreground growth and levelling
There is no explicit levelling, where a character gets a jump in abilities after beating a number of monsters or accumulating an amount of gold. Characters advance through interacting with the game world, having adventures and pursuing their own goals.
Combat as war, not as sport
There is no explicit reward for killing monsters or NPCs. Combat is deadly and unpredictable. If you have no choice but to use physical violence, stack the odds in your favor. Set traps and ambushes. Never fight fair.
Character creation
Vocations over Classes
We are not playing with traditional classes. Players should choose one of the Vocations that offer skills and starting equipment. Characters are not tied to their vocation. If they wish they may follow another vocation through training and interest, or forge something completely unique.
Unlocking kindreds
All starting characters are going to be human. As the players encounter the different sentient species in the Dolmenwood, they will be able to create characters who belong to them.
Troupe Play
Players start off with one character. Their may be times when their character is unavailable to be played (injured, occupied with a project, in a different location etc.). In this case it is useful for a player to have other characters available to play. Hirelings, apprentices, and friendly NPCs are all good options to play until the main character is available again.
Character Advancement
Gold is a good proxy for XP
While their is no explicit XP or leveling, attaining gold can be a route to increasing character power and capabilities. Characters can:

Pay for training to increase stats, HP and skills
Purchase magic items
Use gold to curry favor and gain influence with factions
Hire underlings or mercenaries, build fortifications, research technology

Magic is out in the world
Magic using characters do not get to pick spells from a list during advancement. Magic can be gained is a few different ways:

Finding scrolls and transcribing them into a spell book
Paying a more powerful magic user to teach them a spell
Gaining spells or magical items in exchange for performing services
Praying one of the many shrines to receive a blessing in the form of a new spell

Training
More mundane skills can be acquired through training with a proficient teacher. Some rough guidelines:
Become basically proficient: 1 month, 250GP, can learn from anyone proficient in the skill.
Advanced proficiency: 3 months  500GP, must find a dedicated teacher.
Expert proficiency: 6 months, 1000GP, must find a renowned teacher.
One of the greats in the field, 1 year or more, 2000GP or more, will have to undertake quests, must find a legend in the field willing to teach them.
These are cumulative, so to become an expert at horse riding would take 9 months of dedicated study, cost 1750GP, and require finding an expert at horsemanship to teach them.
